question: Know what you can do with those dishes? And if you ain't man enough to do it yourself, I'd be happy to oblige... Say, look, uh, I gotta have a word with you, if you got a second.
answer: You ain't coming to work?

question: Don't guess. Just come for my day's pay owing and to tell you I'm heading East.
answer: What you gonna do back there, East?

question: Lotta rich women back there...
answer: Yeah?

question: Men, they mostly faggots.
answer: Must be some mess back there.

question: Well, ain't no use hanging around here.
answer: Ain't gonna collect your pay?

question: Oh, poor you. Morey's got terrible ulcers.
answer: Don't know what line Morey's in, but myself now, fact is -- I'm a hustler.

question: Hers'n zodda meg a livig.
answer: Beg pardon, ma'am?

question: Said, a person's gotta make a living.
answer: You sure you heard what I said?

question: Scuse me, hon, fraid I'm only half here. Maybe you oughta run on along. But why don't you take this phone number? Darn! I didn't get to the bank -- Tex -- could you let me have a little coin for the taxi-waxi? You're such a doll. I hate money, don't you? God, it's been fun.
answer: Funny thing, you mentioning money. I was just about to ask your for some...

question: You bastard! You son of a bitch! You think you're dealing with some old slut? Look at me! You think just cause you're a longhorn bull you can get away with this crap? Well, you're out of your mind. I am a gorgeous chick, thirty-one, that's right, you said it!
answer: Hey. Hey, Cass. Did you think I meant that? Christ, would I be asking you for money with a wad like that riding on my hip? Hey. You are a gorgeous-looking piece, Cass. Guy gets horny, just looking at you. It's a fact. How much you need for that taxi? Ten? Twenty? There you go.

question: That is one hell of a shirt. I bet you paid a pretty price for it, am I right?
answer: Oh, it ain't cheap. I mean, yeah, I'd say this was an all right shirt. Don't like to, uh, you know, have a lot of cheap stuff on my back.

question: More goddam faggots in this town.
answer: Shee-it... Kee-rist, you really know the ropes. Wish to hell I bumped into you before. I'm Joe Buck from Texas and I'm gonna buy you a drink, what do you say to that?

question: Enrico Rizzo from the Bronx. Don't mind if I do.
answer: Same all around! For my friend, too! ... you see what I'm getting at here? She got a penthouse up there with color TV and more goddam diamonds than an archbishop and she busts out bawling when I ask for money!

question: For what?
answer: For money.

question: For money for what?
answer: I'm a hustler, hell, didn't you know that?

question: How would I know? You gotta tell a person these things A hustler? Picking up trade on the street like that -- baby, believe me -- you need management.
answer: I think you just put your finger on it, I do.

question: My friend O'Daniel. That's who you need. Operates the biggest stable in town. In the whole goddam metropolitan area. A stud like you - paying! -- not that I blame you -- a dame starts crying, I cut my heart for her... The name is Rizzo.
answer: Hey now, you heard him.

question: That's okay, Joe. I'm used to these types that like to pick on cripples. Sewers're full of 'em. Look, with these chicks that want to buy it, most of 'em are older, dignified, right? Social register types. They can't be trotting down to Times Square to pick out the merchandise. They need a middleman, right? That's O'Daniel. It is a crime, a stud like you passing out double sawbucks to a chick like that. With proper management you should be taking home fifty, a hundred bucks a day. More if you wanta moonlight... Him I placed with O'Daniel just two weeks ago. And look. Not much of a stud either, what I hear...
answer: Hey, listen, how about you take me to mee this Mister O'Diddle bird right now?

question: Well, Joe, you're a nice guy, and I'd be doing you both a favor, but why? What'm I dragging my bum leg all over town for? It's no picnic and what for, for me myself, what? Tomorrow when some piece like that's scratching your back in a Fifth Avenue townhouse, where'll your pal Rizzo be? Nedicks.
answer: Hold it, just hold it. You think I'm that kinda sombitch? Just name your cut, whatever you want, you got it right now. Five? Ten, how's that?

question: Hold it a second... Nine-oh-one, got it? Let's see how you look. Fine. You look fine. Now I'm gonna have to have that other ten...
answer: Ten, ten -- I got a twenty -- take that...

question: Oh hell, forget it.
answer: Now take it. Go on. Listen, where can I reach you? Cause I'm gonna make this right with you soon's I get me set up...

question: Forget it.
answer: I mean, dammit, where you live?

question: You must be Joe Buck. Come in. Am I tickled to find you, boy! Come on in and let's get a look at you. Turn around. Good strong back. You'll need it. So you want help -- take a seat, relax, tell me about yourself. Cowboy, huh?
answer: No sir, I'm no cowboy really, but I'm a first class stud.

question: Take it,easy, boy... Seems to me you're different than a lotta boys that come to me. Most of 'em seem troubled, confused, but I'd say you knew exactly what you want.
answer: You bet I do, sir.

question: But I'll bet you got one thing in common with them other boys. I'll bet you're lonesome.
answer: Well, not too, I mean, a little.

question: I'm lonesome. I'm lonesome so I'm a drunk. I'm lonesome so I'm a dope fiend. I'm lonesome so I'm a thief, a fornicator, a whore-monger. Poop, I say, poop! I've heard it all and I'm sick of it, sick to death.
answer: Yessir, I can see that.

question: Lonesomeness is something you take. You bear? Dammit, you take it and go about your business, that's all.
answer: Well, uh, I'm raring to go.

question: Yes, I believe you are. Cowboy, huh?
answer: Uh, yessir.

question: Ready for hard work, son?
answer: Ready for anything.

question: I got a hunch, Joe Buck, it's gonna be easier for you than most.
answer: Gonna be like money from home.

question: Money from home, see, there's your strength, you put things in earthy terms any man can understand, son. I warn you I'm gonna use you, I'm gonna run you ragged! You're a wonderful boy. You'n me gonna have fun, dammit, it don't have to be joyless. Say, why don't we get right down on our knees now?
answer: Get down -- where?

question: Joe at his hotel window staring out blankly. Gun fire O.S.... Joe curled up on his bed like a baby, fully dressed, his radio on the night stand. O.S. his love theme, remote, hollow... Joe soaking in the tub, eyes closed. Joe staring in the mirror. O.S. static over his love theme. Joe flexing his muscles in his jockey shorts while -- LIVE ON TV SCREEN -- a physical culture personality finishes push-ups and starts pitching his own extra protein bread.
answer: Shee-it.

question: Joe sits in the hotel lobby, staring out at the street, unable to concentrate on his comic book. On two-way radio, a woman's voice giggles as she speaks, "When I can't sleep, well, I just dial the time and listen to those old seconds clicking by like, you know, counting sheep?"
answer: Well, now, ma'am, next time you got that feeling coming on, you dial Joe Buck. I'll show you what to do...

question: I'm awful damn sorry you're sick, kid, but you gonna have to gimme that money like you said. What you got in your pockets? How much's that worth?
answer: Don't hit me, I'm a cripple.

question: Oh, I ain't gonna hit you, I'm gonna strangle you to death... ... only first I'm gonna turn you upside down and shake you out right here and now. What's in your socks?
answer: Not a cent, I swear to God, I swear on my mother's eyes. You keep the sixty-four cents. I want you to have it.

question: It's sticky. What you do, slobber on 'em? I wouldn't touch 'em.
answer: How do you like that O'Daniel, flipping out like that? I wanted to get in touch with you when I heard, but I been laid up with this cold...

question: You want some free medical advice, shut your goddam mouth about that night.
answer: Okay, right, right, okay. Another subject. Where you living? Still at the hotel?

question: Smart thing for me to do is haul ass outta here.
answer: Whatsa matter now?

question: You don't seem like no fag...
answer: What's that supposed to mean?

question: I took 'em off.
answer: What for?

question: So you could sleep! I mean Christ! I drug in a cot, if you want to stay.
answer: Well now, Ratso, I'm gonna tell you something for your own good, only first gimme a cigarette. You want me to stay here tonight, is that the idea?

question: I ain't forcing you, like, I mean, who's forcing you?
answer: Oh. Guess I got the wrong impression.

question: I want you to stay, okay? I goddam invited you, didn't I?
answer: Well, I hope you know what you're in for. I'm a very dangerous person. Someone does me bad like you. If I caught up with you that night, there'd be one dead Ratso long about now. Hear?

question: I'm impressed. You're a killer.
answer: So if you want me to hang around for a few days, I thought you should know. Property of the YMCA. You make me wanna puke sometimes, Ratso.

question: Joe -- do me one favor -- this is my place, am I wrong? You know, in my own place my name ain't Ratso. I mean it so happens my name is Enrico Salvatore Rizzo.
answer: Shee-it, man, I can't say all that.

question: Rico then, at least call me Rico in my own goddam place.
answer: Rico! Rico! Rico! Is that enough? And keep your meat hooks off my radio. Hey, looka here, that ain't nice, picking on a cripple...

question: The two basic items necessary to sustain life are sunshine and coconut milk. That's a known fact. If I can find the goddam hole the milk squirts out.
answer: This is an okay setup you got here, but I'd say you ain't just exactly, uh, flush, is that right or not?

question: I been sick. Hold this, will ya? In Florida, they come smooth, ready to eat. Down there, your only problem is, diet-wise, you gotta lift an arm to wipe warm milk off your chin. Tough, hey?
answer: I think finding you's the smartest thing I ever did, for both of us. You just the crooked kinda sneaky little sidewinder I need to get me hustling in this town. Hey!

question: Miami Beach is the only place for a real hustler. Florida has more rich chicks per square yard than any resort spot in the world. They lie out in their pagodas and pergolas waiting to grab the first jockstrap that passes.
answer: What's all this sweet talk about Florida? Your friend O'Daniel got a stable down there now?

question: Cowboy killers! Break my finger, Christ! I got news for you, baby, no chick with any class buys that big dumb cowboy crap... ... the cowboy bit's out, except among fags of a certain type, which take a certain, type hustler to exploit. Like I could handle it -- being a stealing operation basically -- but take your average fag, very few of them want a cripple.
answer: Well, I am dumb, that's for sure. I don't talk right. I can't think too good. Just only one thing I ever been good for's loving. Women go crazy for me. Fact. Crazy Annie. Had to send her away. So I don't cash in on that, what am I? I'm shee-it. May's well flush me down that hole with the dishwater. That's why you gonna stop crapping about Florida and get your skinny butt moving to earn twenty bucks worth of management you owe me...

question: Look at yourself, Joe, no offense, but frankly, you're beginning to smell. For a stud in this town that's a handicap.
answer: You talk like a man with a tin twat.

question: You ain't got a chance in hell. You need threads and glitter, baby. A front, hey?
answer: Well, uh, my manager's gonna manage all that crap, or else he gonna get a coconut up his flue.

question: Stupid bastard coughed his lungs out breathing that resin all day. They buried him with gloves on. Even the fag undertaker couldn't get his nails clean.
answer: Kee-rist, you pretty damn clever for a skimpy little gimp.

question: You like it? Take a look.
answer: Don't rush me. How I do it, see, I get myself primed, like I was turning on the charm for some pretty little blonde lady, then kinda mosey away slow and easy and - swing around! -- and there you are, you handsome devil.

question: Not bad -- for a cowboy -- you're okay, you're okay.
answer: What I'm gonna do, I'm gonna make a cowboy outta you, kid. How about that? Build you up a little, teach you couple little tricks'n turn y'out to stud, Rat-stuff. Okay, you got yourself one handsome, sweet-smelling cowboy, strut your stuff...

question: Shee-it. Cough yourself inside out, then light a fag, a goddam fag. You make me puke. Where'd you steal it? In the movies?
answer: The coat? A guy I did a favor once gave it to me. Christ.

question: Who'd you ever do a favor for? You just let some poor bastard freeze to death, wouldn't you?
answer: Where'd that come from?

question: Forty-second Street. Where'n hell you think it come from?
answer: You wanna know the truth? You dumb bastard, I got it for you. Look at it. Goddam thing's ten sizes too big for me.

question: Wear it yourself. I wouldn't put it on my back.
answer: Goddamned if I'll wear it!

question: Kee-rist, you sure are one twisty little bastard, Ratso.
answer: The name's Rico, at my own father's grave, a man deserves some respect.

question: Respect shee-it! You even steal flowers for his grave.
answer: Can he smell the difference, eh?

question: Well, uh, he dam well know he ain't 'be-loved Aunt Winifred'.
answer: He can't read. Even dumber than you. Couldn't write his own name. X -- that's what it ought to say there on that goddam headstone. One big lousy X like our flat. Condemned. By order of City Hall.

question: My Grammaw Sally Buck, she died without letting me know.
answer: Just keep your hat on and cry a little. They tip you when it's over.

question: Just ain't right, cheating someone dead and can't cheat back.
answer: You and my old man. Same kinda mind. Putting me down till the day he died... ... why can't you be like your brothers? Sons a father could be proud of. Yeah, sure. My brothers. Too goddam busy making something of themselves to show up when the old man's dying! What was that all about?

question: You wanna read something, read this. I been invited somewhere. They picked me. The only one in the whole goddam place. You see how they looked me over, up and down before they give me that?
answer: So?

question: Well, this thought just struck me. It wasn't too long ago I was washing dishes way the hell somewhere in Texas.
answer: Yeah, well, so?

question: Now I'm here. I'm in New York City. Getting picked for things. Don't you see what I'm driving at?
answer: What you're driving at, you want me to get lost so you can go to your fancy-ass party.

question: Did I say that? Did I? It don't say nothing about you...
answer: Don't say nothing about you either.

question: But they picked me, right? So what I'll do, I'll just say, now look, you want me? Well, I don't go nowhere without my buddy here.
answer: Well, what the hell, I got nothing better to do.

question: Better dry your hair some. You sweating all over the goddam place. You got a comb?
answer: Don't need a comb.

question: Few dozen cooties won't kill me, don't guess.
answer: Okay? I look okay?

question: Better get a hold of someone and tell them I'm here. Well, I made it. This here is Ratso Rizzo and I...
answer: Rico. Rico Rizzo. If you want the word on that brother and sister act, I'll give you the word. That Hansel's a fag and Gretel's got the hots for herself. So who cares, right? Load up on the salami...

question: Twenty bucks...
answer: Sold. Let's go.

question: ... and taxi fare for me.
answer: Get lost.

question: I agree. And for that service I charge one dollar taxi fare.
answer: Your name's Joe. Which is fabulous. Joe could be anyone. Kiss me, Joe, move over, Joe, go away, Joe. It's just perfect. He fell. Hey, fella, you fell. Is he all right?

question: Maybe we should take a little nap, see what happens?
answer: I ain't sleepy.

question: I know. Scribbage!
answer: Shee-it...

question: That's pretty Freudian, Joe.
answer: What? It's a perfectly good word, ain't it. How much time I got? Goddam sand thing drive you crazy. Kee-rist. Spelling never was a very strong point with me. Even in school.

question: If you didn't talk so much, maybe you could think more.
answer: Talking helps. Don't talk, you get muddled in your head. Hey! Now you just look at this here!

question: There's an E in MONEY. If that's your word.
answer: M-O-N-Y -- I'm right! That's just exactly how they spell it up there on that big building, bet you could see it from here. M-O-N-Y.

question: Okay. Never argue with a man.
answer: Y -- what in hell starts with Y?

question: It can end in Y day, pay, lay -- hey, pay lay!
answer: Cut it out. That's cheating, teasing me so I can't think. Just one bitsy Y word and I gonna beat you!

question: You gonna beat me, Joe?
answer: Beat your butt, you don't lemme think!

question: Gay ends in Y. Fey. You like that -- gay fey -- is that your problem?
answer: I show you what problem --

question: See what you think of that crap. I'll pour your soup. Got some of that junk you like to swill, too. Mentholatum. Aspirin. All that shee it... They wrong?
answer: No. But while you was buying the underwear, I could have lifted the socks.

question: You couldn't lift fly specks from a sugar bowl. Can you hold this?
answer: But thanks. Hey, Joe, don't get sore about this or anything. You promise?

question: Yeah.
answer: Well, I don't think I can walk. I mean, I been falling down a lot and, uh...

question: And what?
answer: I'm scared.

question: What of?
answer: What'll happen. I mean what they do to, you know, do with you -- if you can't -- ah, Christ!

question: Who?
answer: I don't know. Cops. Or the -- how should I know?

question: Okay. Here it is. You gonna go see the doctor. I got nine bucks and twenty more Thursday and I gonna be riding high before you know it. So you gonna get you the best goddam doctor in this town and get yourself straightened out, that's what.
answer: No doctors. No, sir. Not me. Doctors are like goddam auto mechanics. Fix one-thing, unplug another. Operate for piles and while they're there, they unscrew your liver. My old man, for God's sake, wasn't any sicker'n I am when he went to the doctor.

question: Well, just exactly what the hell you think you're gonna do? Die on me?
answer: I'm going to Florida, that's my only chance.

question: You know what's wrong with you? You got fevers. You kinky as a bedbug. How you gonna get to Florida?
answer: I'll find the money. If you just get me on the bus, that's all I ask.

question: Just when everything's going my way, you gotta pull a stunt like this.
answer: I don't even want you to go. Whaddya think of that? I got other plans for my life than dragging around some dumb cowboy that thinks he's God's gift to women. One twenty-buck trick and he's already the biggest stud in New York City. It's laughable.

question: I was so childish with her.
answer: What d'you want?

question: What?
answer: What you got me up here for?

question: Oh, difficult, it's so difficult. You're a nice person, Joe -- I should never have asked you up -- a lovely person. Oh, how I loathe life. I loathe it. Please go. Please.
answer: You want me to leave?

question: No, yes. No, I mean yes please go. Help me to be good. Come back tomorrow. Promise.
answer: I'm going to Florida.

question: Listen, I gotta have money.
answer: Oh. Yes. Of course. I should have thought. You shouldn't have to ask. That was thoughtless of me. Yes. Wait here... Here. Don't even thank me.

question: I gotta have more'n ten. I gotta have fifty-seven dollars.
answer: I simply don't have it, Joe.

question: Get outta my way.
answer: You're wasting your time. There's nothing in there.

question: Let go. Let go of the table.
answer: I deserved that, I know I did. I brought this on myself. I'm bleeding, my nose is bleeding, isn't it?

question: You get your first palm tree in South Carolina.
answer: How'n hell a dumb Bronx kid like you know that?

question: I read it.
answer: Shee-it. You believe all you read? If you have to shiver, why don't you pull the blanket up more?

question: I been thinking. I hope we're not gonna have a lotta trouble about my name down there. Because like what's the whole point of this trip anyway?
answer: Keep the goddam blanket on.

question: I mean New York's one thing, but can you see this guy, imagine it, running around the goddam beach all suntan and he's going in swimming, like, and then somebody yells 'Hey, Ratso' -- how does that sound to you?
answer: Sounds like they knew you.

question: Sounds like crap, admit it. And I'm not gonna have it. I'm Rico all the time, okay, do you blame me? That's agreed, okay? We're gonna tell all these new people my name's Rico?
answer: Hey -- whatsa matter?

question: I'm wet.
answer: You're what?

question: I wet my pants! My seat's all wet.
answer: Hell, don't cry about it!

question: Here I am going to Florida and my leg hurts, my butt hurts, my chest hurts, my face hurts, and like that ain't enough, I gotta pee all over myself. I'm falling apart, that's funny?
answer: You just -- just -- what happened, you just had a little rest stop wasn't on the schedule. Hey, what size pants you wear? Couple crullers'n coffee to go. New York.

question: Shee-it, you know, I got this thing all figured out, Ratso. I mean Rico. When we get to Miami, what I'll do, I'll go to work. I gotta do that, 'cause see, I ain't no kind of a hustler. I ain't even any goddam good as a bum. I'm a nothing, that's what I am. So reckon I'd better go to work and get me a goddam job. Okay? Yeah, guess that's what I'm gonna do.
answer: Yes, sir? Your friend's what in the back seat?

question: Dead. Dead as a doornail.
answer: Is this some kind of... Okay, folks, everything's fine. Nothing to worry about. Is he kin to you? Don't you want to close his eyes?

question: Close them?
answer: Just reach over and close them. That's all. I guess we'll just drive on, right? Nothing else to do.

question: No, sir. Not till Miami. I'll see to burying then.
answer: Just a little sickness, folks, nothing serious. We'll be in Miami... ... in forty minutes.
